clinical_study.brief_title: MIND-VR: Virtual Reality for COVID-19 Operators' Psychological Support
clinical_study.official_title: MIND-VR: Virtual Reality for COVID-19 Operators' Psychological Support

lead_sponsor.agency: Fondazione I.R.C.C.S. Istituto Neurologico Carlo Besta

clinical_study.source: Fondazione I.R.C.C.S. Istituto Neurologico Carlo Besta

brief_summary.textblock: COVID-19 pandemic has drastically affected the life of millions of people, with significant socio-economic and psychological impact. Healthcare workers, in particular, are working with high levels of stress and emotional exhaustion, with risk of long term consequences such as stress and anxiety disorders. Previous studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) in preventing and treating stress and anxiety disorders. Therefore,in this study we aim at investigating the advantages of using a virtual reality-based protocol for reducing stress and anxiety in healthcare workers involved in the COVID-19 pandemic.

detailed_description.textblock:
The COVID-19 pandemic is dramatically affecting the daily life of millions of people, with serious socio-economic and mental health consequences. The negative effects on psychological well-being affect all those people forced to isolation and/or quarantine, but above all the medical staff, who works in conditions of high stress and high risk of contagion, and is exposed to a high risk of developing psychopathological symptoms of stress and anxiety disorders.
Numerous scientific studies have shown how virtual reality represents one highly specialized and effective tool for the prevention and treatment of stress-related psychopathological symptoms and anxiety disorders. The use of this immersive technology can in fact help patients both to process the emotional aspects of traumatic memories and to learn how to manage anxiety, including relaxation techniques.
Within this context, the main goal of this study is to investigate the advantages of using a virtual reality-based protocol for reducing stress and anxiety in healthcare workers involved in the COVID-19 pandemic, to better support them in the difficult role of care and care and to better clarify the influence of this methodology in terms of learning important information relating to stress and anxiety (causes, symptoms, management techniques).
In particular, the primary objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of using virtual reality experiences (i.e., a psychoeducational and a relaxing content) in reducing psychopathological symptoms of stress and anxiety in a group of Italian doctors and nurses involved in the COVID-19 crisis (VR Group), compared to a group that will try the same content in a non-immersive mode (i.e., a text for psychoeducation and an audio for relaxation) (Non-VR Group), and a waiting-list (WL Group)
The secondary objectives are:
- To investigate if the use of a virtual psychoeducational experience developed ad hoc on stress and anxiety (i.e., MIND-VR) can facilitate the learning of basic information related to psychopathological symptoms of this conditions of mental suffering (i.e, causes, symptoms, management techniques) compared to a non-immersive modality (i.e., psychoeducational texts).
- To test the efficacy of using a virtual reality relaxation content (i.e., COVID-Feel Good,) for the reduction of stress and anxiety levels of healthcare personnel involved in the care of COVID-19 patients

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The study can be defined as a controlled and randomized clinical trial, single-blind and monocentric, aimed at studying the efficacy of the intervention with virtual reality contents in the reduction of psychopathological symptoms of stress and anxiety in healthcare personnel involved in the care of COVID-19 patients. The study will be conducted according to the indications of Good Clinical Practices. The clinical efficacy of the intervention will be assessed at four different time distances (T0, T1, T2 and T3). The distance between the end of the intervention (T1) and the subsequent follow-up (T2) will be 3 months. A further follow-up (T3) will be carried out 3 months after T2.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in score at the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory -Y2
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; immediately after the procedure/intervention; 3 months and 6 months follow-up
primary_outcome.description: A 20 item measure of the level of the state anxiety

primary_outcome.measure: Change in score at the Perceived Stress Scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; immediately after the procedure/intervention; 3 months and 6 months follow-up
primary_outcome.description: A 10 item measure of the level of stress perceived in the last month

primary_outcome.measure: Change in score at the Depression, Anxiety ans Stress Scale-21 items
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; immediately after the procedure/intervention; 3 months and 6 months follow-up
primary_outcome.description: A 21 item in 3 self-report scales which measures depression, anxiety and stress

primary_outcome.measure: Change in score of knowledge on stress and anxiety
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; immediately after the procedure/intervention; 3 months and 6 months follow-up
primary_outcome.description: A 7 item measure at the ad hoc questionnaire to assess the knowledge of stress and anxiety

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in score at the EQ-5D-5L
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; immediately after the procedure/intervention; 3 months and 6 months follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: A measure which defines the state of health and the perceived quality of life

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in score at the Impact of Event Scale - Revised
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; immediately after the procedure/intervention; 3 months and 6 months follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: A 22 item measure of the subjective stress perception and the factors "intrusion" and "avoidance"

arm_group.description: The treatment for the participants allocated to the VR Group consists of 3 individual sessions of 40 minutes each, for a period of three weeks. The participant in each session will try the virtual reality psychoeducational content (i.e., MIND-VR) for 15 minutes and, subsequently, the virtual content for relaxation (i.e., COVID Feel Good) for 15 minutes.

The treatment for the participants allocated to the Non-VR Group consists of 3 individual sessions of 40 minutes each, for a period of three weeks. Participants allocated to this group will try the contents in a traditional non-immersive modality: for 15 minutes they will be asked to read a PowerPoint presentation containing the same words and images in static form on a desktop of virtual psychoeducational content and, subsequently, to listen for 15 minutes to an audio for relaxation.
The WL Group will undergo pre- and post-protocol tests without undergoing any treatment.

intervention.description: Use of specifically developed VR contents to deliver psychoeducational content on stress and anxiety (i.e., MIND-VR) and to train on relaxation techniques (i.e., COVID Feel Good).

intervention.intervention_name: Text material for psychoeducation and audio for relaxation techniques
intervention.description: Use of non-immersive contents to deliver psychoeducation on stress and anxiety (i.e., a PowerPoint presentation containing the same words and images in static form on a desktop of virtual psychoeducational content), and to train on relaxation techniques (i.e.,listening to an audio for relaxation)
